prior_works.title: Local privacy and statistical minimax rates
prior_works.authors: John C. Duchi, Michael I. Jordan, Martin J. Wainwright
prior_works.role: Foundational LDP minimax framework and interactive vs. non-interactive protocols
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This paper provides the local-DP channel model and minimax lower-bound machinery the authors adapt to the vertically partitioned, two-server setting to derive optimal correlation estimation rates under non-interactive and interactive mechanisms.

prior_works.title: Extremal mechanisms for local differential privacy
prior_works.authors: Peter Kairouz, Sewoong Oh, Pramod Viswanath
prior_works.role: Mechanism design under LDP; optimal privatization for simple statistics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The extremal-mechanism characterizations inform the construction of per-server privatizers (e.g., optimal binary/linear mechanisms) that yield rate-optimal estimators of coordinate-wise moments needed for correlation.

prior_works.title: Inference under information constraints: Lower bounds from chi-square contraction
prior_works.authors: Jayadev Acharya, Clément L. Canonne, Himanshu Tyagi
prior_works.role: General lower-bound technique for privacy/communication constrained inference (including interactivity)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The chi-square contraction framework directly underpins the paper’s minimax lower bounds comparing interactive and non-interactive protocols under heterogeneous local privacy budgets.

prior_works.title: Randomized response: A survey technique for eliminating evasive answer bias
prior_works.role: Primitive LDP mechanism for binary data
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Randomized response serves as a building block for privatizing signs/indicators across servers, enabling unbiased and variance-controlled estimation of cross-moments that feed into the correlation estimator.

prior_works.title: Differentially Private Ordinary Least Squares
prior_works.role: Private covariance/linear regression estimation and inference
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Techniques for privatizing and debiasing second-order statistics and constructing confidence intervals inform the paper’s development of feasible correlation estimators and valid CIs under privacy noise.

prior_works.title: Local, Private, Efficient Protocols for Succinct Histograms
prior_works.role: Algorithmic and lower-bound foundations for non-interactive LDP estimation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Results on optimal non-interactive LDP aggregation and variance/sample complexity guide the paper’s design and analysis of non-interactive two-server mechanisms for estimating correlation from privatized marginals.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core advance—minimax-optimal correlation estimation when X and Y are split across two privacy-constrained servers—rests on the modern local differential privacy (LDP) minimax program and information-constrained inference. Duchi, Jordan, and Wainwright established the channel-based LDP framework and separation between interactive and non-interactive protocols, which this work extends to a vertically partitioned two-server model with heterogeneous (ε,δ) budgets, translating their paradigm to cross-moment estimation needed for correlation. Acharya, Canonne, and Tyagi’s chi-square contraction method supplies a flexible lower-bound toolkit that directly supports the paper’s rate-optimality claims and its comparisons of interaction benefits under asymmetric privacy. On the constructive side, Kairouz, Oh, and Viswanath’s extremal-mechanism results inform the choice of per-server privatization for low-order moments (means and second moments), yielding near-optimal noise-accuracy tradeoffs in both non-interactive and interactive designs. At the mechanism level, Warner’s randomized response provides robust primitives for privatizing binary transforms (e.g., signs/thresholded features) that enable unbiased cross-moment estimation when raw pairs cannot be shared. For inference, Sheffet’s techniques for privately estimating covariance/OLS and forming valid confidence intervals guide the development of debiased correlation estimators with quantifiable uncertainty under injected noise. Finally, Bassily and Smith’s results on optimal non-interactive LDP aggregation anchor the analysis of one-shot protocols, clarifying when interaction is necessary. Together, these works directly enable the paper’s unified characterization of minimax rates and practical procedures for correlation across privacy barriers.
